SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P

<FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">amounts associated with uncertain tax positions of approximately $4.0 billion, including the associated accrued interest of approximately $780 million, from current to
noncurrent. (See <I>Note 7E. Taxes on Income: Tax Contingencies</I>.) </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:8px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>B. Taxes on Income </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT

of&nbsp;$2.3 billion resulting from an agreement in principle with the U.S. Department of Justice to resolve the previously reported investigation regarding allegations of past off-label promotional practices concerning Bextra, as well as certain
other open investigations (see <I>Note 4A</I>. <I>Certain Charges: Bextra and Certain Other Investigations)</I>, and charges of $900 million related to our agreements and our agreements in principle to resolve certain litigation and claims involving
our NSAID pain medicines (see <I>Note 4B</I>. <I>Certain Charges: Certain Product Litigation&#150;Celebrex and Bextra)</I>, and an increase in restructuring charges in 2008 compared to 2007, partially offset by the charges associated with Exubera in
2007 (see <I>Note 4D. Certain Charges: Exubera</I>). The increase in international income from continuing operations before taxes in 2008 compared to 2007 is due primarily to the charges associated with Exubera in 2007 (see <I>Note&nbsp;4D. Certain
Charges: Exubera</I>). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The decrease in domestic income from continuing operations before taxes in 2007 compared to 2006 is due primarily to the volume and geographic
mix of product sales and restructuring charges in 2007 compared to 2006, as well as the impact of charges associated with Exubera, partially offset by lower IPR&amp;D charges in 2007 of $283 million, primarily related to our acquisitions of Biorexis
and Embrex, compared to IPR&amp;D charges in 2006 of $835 million, primarily related to our acquisitions of Rinat and PowderMed. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><I>Provision for taxes on income</I>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">1,992</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD COLSPAN="15" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:4px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Excludes federal, state and international expense of approximately $4 million in 2008, $1 million in 2007, and a benefit of $119
million in 2006, primarily related to the resolution of certain tax positions related to Pharmacia, which were debited or credited to <I>Goodwill</I>, as appropriate. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:10px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2008, we effectively settled certain issues common among multinational corporations with various foreign tax authorities primarily relating to years 2000 through 2005. As a result, we recognized $305 million in tax benefits.
Also, in 2008, we sold one of our biopharmaceutical companies, Esperion Therapeutics, Inc. (Esperion), to a newly formed company that is majority-owned by a group of venture capital firms. The sale, for nominal consideration, resulted in a loss for
tax purposes that reduced our tax expense by $426 million. This tax benefit is a result of the significant initial investment in Esperion in 2004, primarily reported as an income statement charge for in-process research and development at
acquisition date. 2008 also reflects the impact of the third-quarter 2008 provision for the proposed resolution of certain Bextra and Celebrex civil litigation and the impact of the fourth-quarter 2008 provision for the proposed resolution of
certain investigations, which are either not deductible or deductible at lower tax rates. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2006, we were notified by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Appeals
Division that a resolution had been reached on the matter that we were in the process of appealing related to the tax deductibility of an acquisition-related breakup fee paid by the Warner-Lambert Company in 2000. As a result, we recorded a tax
benefit of approximately $441 million related to the resolution of this issue (see <I>Note 7E. Taxes on Income: Tax Contingencies</I>). Also in 2006, we recorded a decrease to the 2005 estimated U.S. tax provision related to the repatriation of
foreign earnings, due primarily to the receipt of information that raised our assessment of the likelihood of prevailing on the technical merits of a certain position, and we recognized a tax benefit of $124 million. Additionally, in 2006, the IRS
issued final regulations on Statutory Mergers and Consolidations, which impacted certain prior-period transactions, and we recorded a tax benefit of $217 million, reflecting the total impact of these regulations. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Amounts reflected in the preceding tables are based on the location of the taxing authorities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="93%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%"></TD></TR>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="5%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="7%"></TD>

<TD></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD COLSPAN="7" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">For earnings taxed at other than the U.S. rate, this rate impact reflects the fact that we operate manufacturing subsidiaries
in Puerto Rico, Ireland and Singapore. We benefit from Puerto Rican incentive grants that expire between 2019 and 2029. Under the grants, we are partially exempt from income, property and municipal taxes. Under Section&nbsp;936 of the U.S. Internal
Revenue Code, Pfizer was a &#147;grandfathered&#148; entity and was entitled to the benefits under such statute until September&nbsp;30, 2006. In Ireland, we benefit from an incentive tax rate effective through 2010 on income from manufacturing
operations. In Singapore, we benefit from incentive tax rates effective through 2031 on income from manufacturing operations. This rate impact also reflects the jurisdictional location of earnings, realization of approximately $711 million (tax
effect) in net operating losses, as well as the costs of certain repatriation decisions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">For a discussion about the sale of the biopharmaceutical company, proposed
legal settlements, the tax legislation impact and the repatriation of foreign earnings, see <I>Note 7B. Taxes on Income: Taxes on Income</I>. For a discussion about the resolution of certain tax positions, see <I>Note 7E. Taxes on Income: Tax
Contingencies</I>. On October&nbsp;3, 2008, the Tax Extenders and Alternative Minimum Tax Relief Act (the Extenders Act) extended the research and development tax credit from January&nbsp;1, 2008, through December&nbsp;31, 2009. The charges for
acquired IPR&amp;D in 2008, 2007 and 2006 are primarily not deductible. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>D. Deferred Taxes </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Deferred taxes arise as a result of basis differentials between financial statement accounting and tax amounts. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The tax effect of the major
items recorded as deferred tax assets and liabilities, shown before jurisdictional netting, as of December&nbsp;31, is as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD COLSPAN="19" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The reduction in the net deferred tax liability position in 2008 compared to 2007 is primarily due to amortization of
noncurrent deferred tax liabilities related to identifiable intangibles in connection with our acquisition of Pharmacia in 2003, an increase in the noncurrent deferred tax asset on employee benefits and net operating loss carryovers, and an increase
in the current deferred tax asset on restructuring charges, partially offset by an increase in the current deferred tax liability on unremitted earnings. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We have
carryforwards, primarily related to foreign tax credit carryovers and net operating loss carryovers, which are available to reduce future U.S. federal and state, as well as international, income with either an indefinite life or expiring at various
times between 2009 and 2028. Certain of our U.S. net operating losses are subject to limitations under Internal Revenue Code Section&nbsp;382. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="93%"></TD></TR>

<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>60</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:14px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px">&nbsp;</P></TD>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Valuation allowances are provided when we believe that our deferred tax assets are not recoverable
based on an assessment of estimated future taxable income that incorporates ongoing, prudent, feasible tax planning strategies. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we have
not made a U.S. tax provision on approximately $63.1 billion of unremitted earnings of our international subsidiaries. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, these earnings are intended to be permanently reinvested overseas; as such, it is not practical to
compute the estimated deferred tax liability on these permanently reinvested earnings. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Deferred tax assets and liabilities in the preceding table, netted by taxing
jurisdiction, are in the following captions in our consolidated balance sheets: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Current deferred tax liability<SUP>(c)</SUP></FONT></P></TD>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" COLSPAN="8"> <P STYLE="font-size:4px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;Included in
<I>Taxes and other current assets</I>.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(b)</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;Included in <I>Other assets, deferred taxes and deferred
charges</I>.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(c)</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;Included in <I>Other current liabilities</I>.</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(d)</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;Included in <I>Deferred taxes</I>.</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="font-size:4px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP></SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I></I>&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP></SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I></I>&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP></SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I></I>&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP></SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I></I>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>E. Tax Contingencies </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We are
subject to income tax in many jurisdictions and a certain degree of estimation is required in recording the assets and liabilities related to income taxes. For a description of our accounting policy associated with accounting for income tax
contingencies, see <I>Note 1O. Significant Accounting Policies: Income Tax Contingencies</I>. All of our tax positions are subject to audit by the local taxing authorities in each tax jurisdiction. Tax audits can involve complex issues and the
resolution of issues may span multiple years, particularly if subject to negotiation or litigation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The United States is one of our major tax jurisdictions. We are
currently appealing two issues related to the IRS&#146; audits of the Pfizer Inc. tax returns for the years 2002 through 2005. The 2006, 2007 and 2008 tax years are currently under audit as part of the IRS Compliance Assurance Process, a real-time
audit process. All other tax years in the U.S. for Pfizer Inc. are closed under the statute of limitations. With respect to Pharmacia Corporation, the IRS is currently conducting an audit for the year 2003 through the date of merger with Pfizer
(April 16, 2003). In addition to the open audit years in the U.S., we have open audit years in other major tax jurisdictions, such as Canada (1998-2008), Japan (2006-2008), Europe (1996-2008, primarily reflecting Ireland, the U.K., France, Italy,
Spain and Germany) and Puerto Rico (2004-2008). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We regularly reevaluate our tax positions based on the results of audits of federal, state and foreign income tax
filings, statute of limitations expirations, and changes in tax law that would either increase or decrease the technical merits of a position relative to the &#145;more-likely-than-not&#146; standard. We believe that our accruals for tax liabilities
are adequate for all open years. Many factors are considered in making these evaluations, including past history, recent interpretations of tax law, and the specifics of each matter. Because tax laws and regulations are subject to interpretation and
tax litigation is inherently uncertain, these evaluations can involve a series of complex judgments about future events and can rely heavily on estimates and assumptions (see <I>Note 1C. Significant Accounting Policies: Estimates and
Assumptions</I>). Our evaluations are based on estimates and assumptions that have been deemed reasonable by management. However, if our estimates and assumptions are not representative of actual outcomes, our results could be materially impacted.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2008, we effectively settled certain issues common among multinational corporations with various foreign tax authorities primarily relating to tax years 2000 to
2005. As a result, we recognized $305 million in tax benefits. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Because tax law is complex and often subject to varied interpretations, it is uncertain whether some
of our tax positions will be sustained upon audit. The amounts associated with uncertain tax positions in 2008 and 2007 are as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Tax liabilities associated with uncertain tax positions represent unrecognized tax benefits, which
arise when the estimated benefit recorded in our financial statements differs from the amounts taken or expected to be taken in a tax return because of the uncertainties described above. These unrecognized tax benefits relate primarily to issues
common among multinational corporations. Substantially all of these unrecognized tax benefits, if recognized, would impact our effective income tax rate. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Tax assets
associated with uncertain tax positions represent our estimate of the potential tax benefits in one tax jurisdiction that could result from the payment of income taxes in another tax jurisdiction. These potential benefits generally result from
cooperative efforts among taxing authorities, as required by tax treaties to minimize double taxation, commonly referred to as the competent authority process. The recoverability of these assets, which we believe to be more likely than not, is
dependent upon the actual payment of taxes in one tax jurisdiction and, in some cases, the successful petition for recovery in another tax jurisdiction. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">A
reconciliation of the beginning and ending amounts of gross unrecognized tax benefits and accrued interest is as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center" BGCOLOR="#ffffff">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="88%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="3%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="1%"></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">(MILLIONS OF DOLLARS)</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="right" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="right" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">2007</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;<FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Balance, January&nbsp;1</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>$</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>(6,654</B></FONT></TD>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)&nbsp;</SUP></FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Decreases are primarily a result of effectively settling certain issues with various foreign tax authorities for a net benefit of
$305 million, reflecting the reversal of the related tax assets associated with the competent authority process (<I>see Note 7B. Taxes on Income: Taxes on Income</I>). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(b)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Primarily included in <I>Provision for taxes</I> <I>on income</I>. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(c)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Includes increases based on tax positions taken during a prior period, decreases due to settlements with taxing authorities and
decreases as a result of a lapse of the applicable statute of limitations. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(d)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2008, included in <I>Income taxes payable </I>($85 million), <I>Taxes and other current assets </I>($44 million) and <I>Other
taxes payable </I>($6.6 billion). In 2007, included in <I>Income</I> <I>taxes payable</I> ($358 million), <I>Taxes and other current assets</I> ($50 million) and <I>Other taxes payable</I> ($6.2 billion). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">If our estimates of unrecognized tax benefits and potential tax benefits are not representative of actual outcomes, our financial statements could be materially affected in the
period of settlement or when the statutes of limitations expire, as we treat these events as discrete items in the period of resolution. Finalizing audits with the relevant taxing authorities can include formal administrative and legal proceedings
and, as a result, it is difficult to estimate the timing and range of possible change related to our uncertain tax positions. However, any settlements or statute expirations would likely result in a significant decrease in our uncertain tax
positions. We estimate that within the next 12 months, our gross uncertain tax positions could decrease by as much as $200 million, as a result of settlements with taxing authorities or the expiration of the statute of limitations. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Includes pre-tax amounts for <I>Actuarial losses </I>of $4.3 billion and <I>Prior service costs/(credits) and other </I>of $27
million. See also <I>Note 13A. Pension and Postretirement Benefit Plans and Defined Contribution Plans:</I> <I>Adoption of New Accounting Standard</I>. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Income taxes are not provided for foreign currency translation relating to permanent investments in international subsidiaries. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">As of December&nbsp;31,
2008, we estimate that we will reclassify into 2009 income the following pre-tax amounts currently held in <I>Accumulated other comprehensive income/(expense)</I>: virtually all of the unrealized holding gains on derivative financial instruments;
$302 million of actuarial losses related to benefit plan obligations and plan assets and other benefit plan items; and $6 million of prior service credits related primarily to benefit plan amendments. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>B. Short-Term Borrowings </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Short-term borrowings include amounts for commercial paper of $7.8 billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, and $4.4 billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. The weighted-average effective interest rate on short-term borrowings outstanding was
1.9% as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, and 3.4% as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had access to $7.2 billion of lines of credit, of which
$5.1 billion expire within one year. Of these lines of credit, $7.1 billion are unused, of which our lenders have committed to loan us $6.1 billion at our request. $6.0 billion of the unused lines of credit, of which $4.0 billion expire in 2009 and
$2.0 billion expire in 2013, may be used to support our commercial paper borrowings. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>C. Long-Term Debt </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Information about our long-term debt as of December&nbsp;31 follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008 Financial Report&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>65</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:14px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In March 2007, we filed a securities registration statement with the Securities and Exchange
Commission. The registration statement was filed under the automatic shelf registration process available to &#147;well-known seasoned issuers&#148; and is effective for three years. We can issue securities of various types under that registration
statement at any time, subject to approval by our Board of Directors in certain circumstances. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>D. Derivative Financial Instruments and Hedging Activities </B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>Foreign Exchange Risk</B>&#151;A significant portion of revenues, earnings and net investments in foreign affiliates is exposed to changes in foreign exchange
rates. We seek to manage our foreign exchange risk in part through operational means, including managing expected same currency revenues in relation to same currency costs and same currency assets in relation to same currency liabilities. Depending
on market conditions, foreign exchange risk is also managed through the use of derivative financial instruments and foreign currency debt. These financial instruments serve to protect net income and net investments against the impact of the
translation into U.S. dollars of certain foreign exchange denominated transactions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We entered into financial instruments to hedge, or offset by the same currency,
an appropriate portion of the currency risk and the timing of the hedged or offset item. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, the more significant financial instruments employed to manage foreign exchange risk follow: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:4px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center" BGCOLOR="#ffffff">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Forwards = Forward-exchange contracts; ST yen borrowings = Short-term yen borrowings; ST yen debt = Short-term yen debt; LT yen
debt = Long-term yen debt. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(b)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The primary consolidated balance sheet caption indicates the financial statement classification of the amount associated with the
financial instrument used to hedge or offset foreign exchange risk. The abbreviations used are defined as follows: OCA = <I>Taxes and other current assets</I>; OA = <I>Other assets, deferred taxes and deferred charges</I>; STB = <I>Short-term
borrowings, including current portion of long-term debt</I>; OCL = <I>Other current liabilities</I>; LTD = <I>Long-term debt</I>; and ONCL = <I>Other noncurrent liabilities</I>. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(c)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">CF = Cash flow hedge; NI = Net investment hedge. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(d)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Forward-exchange contracts used to offset short-term foreign currency assets and liabilities were primarily for intercompany
transactions in euros, Japanese yen, Swedish krona and U.K. pounds for both years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(e)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2007, reflects an increase in Swedish krona net investments due to the receipt of proceeds related to the sale of our Consumer
Healthcare business in Sweden in late 2006. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">All derivative contracts used to manage foreign currency risk are measured at fair value and reported
as assets or liabilities on the consolidated balance sheet. Changes in fair value are reported in earnings or deferred, depending on the nature and purpose of the financial instrument (offset or hedge relationship) and the effectiveness of the hedge
relationships, as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We recognize the earnings impact of foreign currency swaps and foreign currency forward-exchange contracts designated as cash flow hedges in <I>Other
(income)/deductions&#151;net </I>upon the recognition of the foreign exchange gain or loss on the translation to U.S. dollars of the hedged items. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We recognize the earnings impact of foreign currency swaps and forward-exchange contracts that are used to offset foreign currency assets or liabilities in <I>Other
(income)/deductions&#151;net </I>during the terms of the contracts, along with the earnings impact of the items they generally offset. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We recognize the earnings impact of foreign currency swaps designated as a hedge of our net investments in <I>Other (income)/deductions&#151;net </I>in three ways: over
time-for the periodic net swap payments; immediately-to the extent of any change in the difference between the foreign exchange spot rate and forward rate; and upon sale or substantial liquidation of our net investments-to the extent of change in
the foreign exchange spot rates. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Any ineffectiveness in a hedging relationship is recognized immediately into earnings. There was no
significant ineffectiveness in 2008, 2007 or 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>Interest Rate Risk&#151;</B>Our interest-bearing investments, loans and borrowings are subject to interest rate
risk. We invest, loan and borrow primarily on a short-term or variable-rate basis. From time to time, depending on market conditions, we will fix interest rates either through entering into fixed-rate investments and borrowings or through the use of
derivative financial instruments. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We entered into derivative financial instruments to hedge or offset the fixed interest rates on the hedged item, matching the
amount and timing of the hedged item. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and 2007, the more significant derivative financial instruments employed to manage interest rate risk follow: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">U.S. dollar fixed rate debt<SUP>(c)</SUP></FONT></P></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">450</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">2008</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD COLSPAN="20" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The primary consolidated balance sheet caption indicates the financial statement classification of the fair value amount
associated with the financial instrument used to hedge or offset interest rate risk. The abbreviations used are defined as follows: OCA = <I>Taxes and other current assets</I>; OCL = <I>Other current liabilities</I>; ONCL = <I>Other noncurrent
liabilities</I>; and OA = <I>Other assets, deferred taxes and deferred charges</I>. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(b)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">FV = Fair value hedge. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(c)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Serve to reduce exposure to long-term U.S. dollar and euro interest rates by effectively converting fixed rates associated with
long-term debt obligations to floating rates (see also <I>Note 9C. Financial Instruments: Long-Term Debt</I>). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">All derivative contracts used to
manage interest rate risk are measured at fair value and reported as assets or liabilities on the consolidated balance sheet. Changes in fair value are reported in earnings, as follows: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We recognize the earnings impact of interest rate swaps designated as fair value hedges in <I>Other (income)/deductions&#151;net </I>upon the recognition of the change in
fair value of the hedged risk. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We recognize the earnings impact of interest rate swaps that serve as offsets immediately in <I>Other (income)/deductions</I>&#151;<I>net</I>. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Any ineffectiveness in a hedging relationship is recognized immediately in earnings. There was no significant ineffectiveness in 2008, 2007 or 2006. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="93%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008 Financial Report&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>67</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:14px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Fair values are determined based on valuation techniques categorized as follows: Level 1 means the use of quoted prices for
identical instruments in active markets; Level 2 means the use of quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets or quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active or are directly or indirectly observable;
Level 3 means the use of unobservable inputs. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(b)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Included in <I>Long-term investments and loans</I>. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(c)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Included in <I>Short-term investments</I> ($20.9 billion) and <I>Long-term investments and loans</I> ($9.2 billion).
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(d)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Included in <I>Short-term investments</I>. Virtually all of these money market funds participate in the U.S. Treasury
Department&#146;s Temporary Guarantee Program for Money Market Funds. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(e)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><I></I>Included in<I> Taxes and other current assets</I> ($404 million) and <I>Other assets, deferred taxes and deferred
charges</I> ($855 million). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(f)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Included in <I>Cash and cash equivalents</I> ($2.0 billion), <I>Short-term investments</I> ($355 million) and <I>Long-term
investments and loans</I> ($14 million). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(g)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Included in <I>Other current liabilities</I> ($1.1 billion) and <I>Other noncurrent liabilities</I> ($124 million).
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The differences between the estimated fair values and carrying values of our financial assets and liabilities not carried at fair value on a
recurring basis were not significant as of December&nbsp;31, 2008. See also <I>Note 9A. Financial Instruments: Investments in Debt and Equity Securities</I>. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">As of
December&nbsp;31, 2008, the following methods and assumptions were used to estimate the fair value of our financial assets and liabilities: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Trading securities&#151;we use quoted market prices. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Available-for-sale debt securities&#151;we use a matrix-pricing model using observable market quotes and credit ratings. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Available-for-sale money market funds&#151;we use observable prices. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Available-for-sale equity securities, excluding money market funds&#151;we use pricing services that principally use a composite of observable prices.
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Derivative financial instruments (assets and liabilities)&#151;we use a matrix-pricing model using observable market quotes and credit ratings. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Held-to-maturity debt securities&#151;we use a matrix-pricing model using observable market quotes and credit ratings. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Short-term and long-term loans&#151;we use discounted future cash flows using current rates at which similar loans would be made to borrowers with similar credit ratings and
for the same remaining maturities. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Non-traded equity securities&#151;we apply the implied volatility associated with an observable biotech index to the carrying amount of our portfolio.
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Short-term borrowings and long-term debt&#151;we use a matrix-pricing model using observable market quotes and our own credit rating. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In addition, we have long-term receivables where fair value uses discounted future cash flows, using current rates at which similar loans would be made to borrowers with similar
credit ratings and for the same remaining maturities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008 Financial Report</B></FONT></TD></TR>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We regularly evaluate all of our financial assets for impairment. For investments in debt and equity
securities, when a decline in fair value, if any, is determined to be other-than-temporary, an impairment charge is recorded and a new cost basis in the investment is established. For loans, an impairment charge is recorded if it is probable that we
will not be able to collect all amounts due according to the loan agreement. There were no significant impairments recognized in 2008, 2007 or 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>F. Credit
Risk </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We regularly review the creditworthiness of counterparties to foreign exchange and interest rate agreements and do not expect to incur a significant loss
from failure of any counterparties to perform under the agreements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">There are no significant concentrations of credit risk related to our financial instruments with
any individual counterparty. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had $3.8 billion due from a well-diversified, highly rated group (primarily Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s rating of AA or better) of bank counterparties around the world. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In general, there is no requirement for collateral from customers. However, derivative financial instruments are executed under master netting agreements with financial
institutions. These agreements contain provisions that provide for the ability for collateral payments, depending on levels of exposure, our credit rating and the credit rating of the counterparty. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we advanced cash
collateral of $497 million and received cash collateral of $510 million against various counterparties. The collateral primarily supports the approximate fair value of our derivative contracts. The collateral advanced receivables are reported in
<I>Short-term loans</I>, and the collateral received obligations are reported in <I>Short-term borrowings, including current portion of long-term debt.</I> </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">10</FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3">. Inventories </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The components of inventories as of December&nbsp;31 follow: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)</SUP>&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2008, primarily related to our acquisitions of Coley and a number of animal health product lines from Schering-Plough, as well
as two smaller acquisitions also related to Animal Health. In 2007, primarily related to our acquisition of Embrex. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;padding-bottom:6px; margin-top:-3px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:80%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2008, primarily relates to tax adjustments and the impact of foreign exchange. In 2007, primarily relates to the impact of
foreign exchange. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008 Financial Report&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>69</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:14px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>

SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P

<TD COLSPAN="27" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="25"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="24"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(a)</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;Includes patents, non-compete agreements, customer contracts and other
intangible assets.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP>(b)</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;Decrease was primarily related to amortization and the impact of foreign
exchange, partially offset by acquisitions.</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP></SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px; margin-left:1.29em; text-indent:-1.29em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP></SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:8px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Developed technology rights represent the amortized value associated with developed technology, which has been acquired from
third parties and which can include the right to develop, use, market, sell and/or offer for sale the product, compounds and intellectual property that we have acquired with respect to products, compounds and/or processes that have been completed.
We possess a well-diversified portfolio of hundreds of developed technology rights across therapeutic categories, primarily representing the commercialized products included in our Pharmaceutical segment that we acquired in connection with our
Pharmacia acquisition in 2003. While the Arthritis and Pain therapeutic category represents about 29% of the total amortized value of developed technology rights as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the balance of the amortized value is distributed in a
range of 5% to 15% across the following Pharmaceutical therapeutic product categories: Ophthalmology; Oncology; Urology; Infectious and Respiratory Diseases; Endocrine Disorders categories; and as a group, the Cardiovascular and Metabolic Diseases,
Central Nervous System Disorders and All Other categories. The significant components include values determined for Celebrex, Detrol/Detrol LA, Xalatan, Genotropin and Zyvox. Also included in this category are the post-approval milestone payments
made under our alliance agreements for certain Pharmaceutical products, such as Rebif and Spiriva. These rights are all subject to our review for impairment, explained in <I>Note 1K. Significant Accounting Policies: Amortization of Intangible
Assets, Depreciation and Certain Long-Lived Assets.</I> </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:8px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The weighted-average life of our total finite-lived intangible assets is approximately seven years, which
includes developed technology rights at eight years. Total amortization expense for finite-lived intangible assets was $2.8 billion in 2008, $3.2 billion in 2007 and $3.4 billion in 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:8px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">Brands represent the amortized value associated with tradenames, as the products themselves no longer receive patent protection. Most of these assets are associated with our Pharmaceutical segment and the significant components
include values determined for Depo-Provera, Xanax and Medrol. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:8px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">In 2007, we recorded charges of $1.1 billion in <I>Cost of sales</I> and <I>Selling, informational and
administrative expenses</I> related to the impairment of Exubera (included in our Pharmaceutical segment) (see <I>Note 4D. Certain Charges: Exubera</I>). In 2006, we recorded charges of $320 million in <I>Other</I> <I>(income)/deductions&#151;net
</I>related to the impairment of our Depo-Provera brand, a contraceptive injection (included in our Pharmaceutical segment). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:8px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The annual amortization expense expected
for the years 2009 through 2013 is as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="4">13.</FONT><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"> Pension and Postretirement
Benefit Plans and Defined Contribution Plans </FONT></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:8px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We provide defined benefit pension plans and defined contribution plans for the majority of our employees
worldwide. In the U.S., we have both qualified and supplemental (non-qualified) defined benefit plans. A qualified plan meets the requirements of certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code and, generally, contributions to qualified plans are tax
deductible. A qualified plan typically provides benefits to a broad group of employees and may not discriminate in favor of highly compensated employees in its coverage, benefits or contributions. We also provide benefits through supplemental
(non-qualified) retirement plans to certain employees. In addition, we provide medical and life insurance benefits to certain retirees and their eligible dependents through our postretirement plans. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">We use a measurement date that coincides with our fiscal year-ends; December&nbsp;31 for our U.S. pension and postretirement plans and November&nbsp;30 for our international plans.
During 2006, pursuant to the divestiture of our Consumer Healthcare business, certain defined benefit obligations and related plan assets, if applicable, were transferred to the purchaser of that business. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>A. Adoption of New Accounting Standard </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, we adopted the
provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;158, <I>Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans (an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106 and 132R), </I>which requires us to recognize on our balance sheet the
difference between our benefit obligations and any plan assets of our defined benefit plans. In addition, we are required to recognize as part of other comprehensive income/(expense), net of taxes, gains and losses due to differences between our
actuarial assumptions and actual experience (actuarial gains and losses) and any effects on prior service due to plan amendments (prior service costs or credits) that arise during the period and are not being recognized as net periodic benefit
costs. Upon adoption, SFAS 158 requires the recognition of previously unrecognized actuarial gains and losses, prior service costs and credits and net transition amounts within <I>Accumulated other comprehensive income/(expense), </I>net of tax. The
incremental impact of applying SFAS 158 to our balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, was to reduce our total shareholders&#146; equity by $2.1 billion, primarily due to the recognition of previously unrecognized actuarial losses. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="2"><B>B. Components of Net Periodic Benefit Costs and Other Amounts Recognized in Other Comprehensive (Income)/Expense </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The annual cost and other amounts recognized in other comprehensive (income)/expense of the U.S. qualified, U.S. supplemental (non-qualified) and international pension plans and
postretirement plans for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and 2006, follow: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:4px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The decrease in the 2008 U.S. qualified pension plans&#146; net periodic benefit cost compared to 2007 was largely driven by
the increase in the discount rate and the impact of our cost-reduction initiatives. The decrease in the 2007 U.S. qualified pension plans&#146; net periodic benefit cost compared to 2006 was largely driven by a higher 2006 actual investment return,
the increase in the discount rate and the impact of our cost-reduction initiatives. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The increase in the 2008 U.S. supplemental (non-qualified) plans&#146; net
periodic benefit costs compared to 2007 was largely driven by settlement charges required to be recognized due to lump sum benefit payments made to certain of our former executive officers and other former executives in 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008 Financial Report&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>71</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:14px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="3"><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL"
SIZE="1">Pfizer Inc and Subsidiary Companies </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The decrease in the 2007 international plans&#146; net periodic benefit cost compared to 2006 was
largely driven by a settlement gain at our Japanese affiliate. Japanese pension regulations permit employers with certain pension obligations to separate the social security benefits portion of those obligations and transfer it, along with related
plan assets, to the Japanese government. During 2007, our Japanese affiliate completed this transfer and effectively received a subsidy from the Japanese government of approximately $168 million. This subsidy was the result of the transfer of
pension obligations of approximately $309 million (excluding the effect of any future salary increases of approximately $9 million) along with related plan assets of approximately $141 million. This transfer resulted in a settlement gain of
approximately $106 million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The following table presents the amount in <I>Accumulated other comprehensive income/(expense) </I>expected to be amortized into 2009
net periodic benefit costs: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:3px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:3.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">International pension plans</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>3.3</B></FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" BGCOLOR="#bfbfbf"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">3.6</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">3.6</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD COLSPAN="12" VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The assumptions above are used to develop the benefit obligations at fiscal year-end and to develop the net periodic benefit
cost for the subsequent fiscal year. Therefore, the assumptions used to determine net periodic benefit cost for each year are established at the end of each previous year, while the assumptions used to determine benefit obligations were established
at each year-end. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The net periodic benefit cost and the benefit obligations are based on actuarial assumptions that are reviewed on an annual basis. We revise these
assumptions based on an annual evaluation of long-term trends, as well as market conditions that may have an impact on the cost of providing retirement benefits. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1">The
expected rates of return on plan assets for our U.S. qualified, international and postretirement plans represent our long-term assessment of return expectations, which we may change based on shifts in economic and financial market conditions. The
2008 expected rates of return for these plans reflect our long-term outlook for a globally diversified portfolio, which is influenced by a combination of return expectations for individual asset classes, actual historical experience and our
diversified investment strategy. The historical returns are one of the inputs used to provide context for the development of our expectations for future returns. Using this information, we develop ranges of returns for each asset class and a
weighted-average expected return for our targeted portfolio, which includes the impact of portfolio diversification and active portfolio management. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="93%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>72</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:14px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px">&nbsp;</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="ARIAL" SIZE="1"><B>2008 Financial Report</B></FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
